units.title: DisCo machine‑vision cell detection
units.text: DisCo depends on machine-vision to actively detect cells and coordinate their capture in droplets, allowing for continuous operation and enabling free per-run scaling and serial processing of samples.
units.rationale: Describes the core detection step enabling deterministic co‑encapsulation.

units.title: Measurement of cell capture efficiency
units.text: We processed cell numbers of between 50 and 200 cells, of which 74.9% (s.d. ±10.7%) of input cells had more than 500 unique molecular identifiers (UMIs) per cell (Fig. 1j).
units.rationale: Provides a quantitative assessment of how many input cells are successfully captured.

units.title: Co‑encapsulation purity assessment
units.text: We found that on average, 91.4% of all droplets contain a cell and a bead, and only 1.7% contain an independent cell doublet (Fig. 1f).
units.rationale: Evaluates the proportion of droplets with the desired single‑cell, single‑bead composition.

units.title: Species‑mixing validation experiment
units.text: we performed a species mixing experiment of human embryonic kidney (HEK) 293T and murine immortalized brown pre‑adipocyte (IBA) cells.
units.rationale: Uses mixed species to verify barcode assignment and cross‑contamination rates.

units.title: Impedance‑based input cell counting
units.text: to generate monodisperse emulsions with high co‑encapsulation purity (Fig. 1e and Supplementary Video 2). counting of the number of input cells using impedance measurements, which enabled accurate counting of the number of input cells as validated by microscopy (Extended Data Fig. 2f).
units.rationale: Ensures precise knowledge of how many cells enter the device for efficiency calculations.

units.title: Microvalve‑driven droplet generation
units.text: implementation of Quake-style microvalves to facilitate flow control during operation; the development of a machine‑vision‑based approach utilizing subsequent image subtraction for blob detection to move particles into the target region of interest with 95.9% of particles placed in the ~200‑μm‑wide region.
units.rationale: Details the fluidic control mechanisms that produce uniform droplets.

units.title: Time‑dependent quality assessment
units.text: we assessed time‑dependent effects on the quality of the single cell data by analyzing HEK 293T cells that were loaded on our system (at 22 °C (room temperature)) for 0–20, 20–40 and 40–60 min. Furthermore, we sampled cells that were stored for 120 and 180 min on ice.
units.rationale: Tests how processing delays impact transcriptomic quality metrics.

units.title: Low‑input sample benchmarking
units.text: DisCo efficiently captures cells from low‑input samples. As a first benchmarking experiment, we set out to determine the cell capture efficiency and the bead and cell co‑encapsulation purity of DisCo.
units.rationale: Establishes performance baselines for samples with very few cells.

units.title: Comparison with Fluidigm C1 platform
units.text: We chose the 96‑trap chip given that, according to the user manual, it is the more suitable chip for low cell inputs. We found that the Fluidigm C1 system achieves processing speed could be increased to 350 cells per hour, although with a decreased capture efficiency of approximately 75%.
units.rationale: Provides a reference point against an existing low‑input technology.

units.title: Droplet capture observation
units.text: The droplet capture process as observed on‑chip. Valves are highlighted according to their actuation state (red, closed; green, open).
units.rationale: Visual confirmation of valve states during droplet formation.
